channel.title: briefUpdatesBreakingOffshootNL
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from briefUpdatesBreakingOffshootNL, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: It Was Supposed to Connect Segregated Neighborhoods. Did It Gentrify Them Instead?
item.description: The Atlanta Beltline turned a mostly derelict 22-mile loop around the city into a wildly popular — and profitable — urban park. It also contributed to...

item.title: Dozens of scientists find errors in a new Energy Department climate report
item.description: More than 85 scientists say that a recent U.S. Department of Energy report is full of errors and misrepresents climate science.

item.title: Why China Is Trying to Tame Its Electric Car Frenzy
item.description: Beijing has run out of patience with companies slashing prices, and is urging restraint. But fierce competition is also producing a surge of innovatio...

item.title: After Deadly Earthquake in Afghanistan, Emergency Aid Trickles In
item.description: Villages remain cut off in the remote, mountainous areas in the east that have been hardest hit by the disaster, which has killed at least 1,400 peopl...

item.title: A California judge rules that Trump's deployment of the guard to LA was illegal
item.description: President Trump took control of the state's National Guard in June and deployed it to Los Angeles to face anti-immigration protestors and assist offic...

item.title: Congress returns to Washington. And, Brazil's ex-president starts trial today
item.description: Congress returns to the nation's capital as the deadline to avoid a government shutdown looms. And, Brazil's former president is on trial for attempti...

item.title: Kraft Heinz is splitting up, separating hot dogs from ketchup
item.description: One of the world's largest food brands is splitting apart a decade after a messy megamerger staged by Warren Buffett.

item.title: These scientists found Alzheimer's in their genes. Here's what they did next
item.description: Three scientists learned they carry genes that dramatically increase their risk for Alzheimer's disease. Now they're working to keep their brains heal...

item.title: First War, Then Floods Drive Pakistani Families From Their Homes
item.description: Near the Indian border, many people who fled the recent India-Pakistan conflict have had to leave again, this time because of rising waters.

item.title: How Protests, Tear Gas and Looting Roiled Indonesia
item.description: Deep-rooted resentment between the haves and have-nots set off a wave of antigovernment protests that have turned violent.

item.title: White House Counsel Eases Trump’s Path on Aggressive Agenda
item.description: David Warrington, the top lawyer inside the West Wing, focuses on “the art of the possible,” as one Trump adviser said.

item.title: Afghans Reel From Deadly Quake
item.description: Rescue workers struggled to reach communities in the isolated, mountainous area hit by the earthquake. The Afghan authorities said at least 1,400 peop...

item.title: What to Know About the Earthquake in Afghanistan
item.description: At least 1,400 people were killed and more than 3,100 others injured, according to the Afghan authorities, and the death toll was expected to rise.

item.title: What It Was Like Inside Syria’s Most Fearsome Prison
item.description: For decades, the Assad regime locked up its opponents in prisons like Sednaya. The New York Times created a 3-D model of the prison and its brutal con...
